title: Before 29 December 2017, will it be announced that Chinese troops are deploying to the disputed border region between Eritrea and Djibouti?
preds: It is highly unlikely that China will deploy troops to the region in the next 24 hours.

Given that China's military presence in China is a recent development and China's first international military base in its modern era, China is extremely unlikely to make any moves that (a) bring additional focus to said presence or (b) portrays the Chinese Army in an aggressive light. This forecast assumes (1) no quick-turn UN resolution that authorizes such a peacekeeping mission, (2) no immediate threat to Chinese forces stationed in Djibouti, and (3) no quick-turn request by both Eritrea and Djibouti for China to implement such a presence.
No report of happening as of 12/26/17. Djibouti news re Chinese is about investment. Military talks are with EU.
No news, China would want to announce its involvement
At this late date no further news has come out. Precursor news has also failed to indicate there is still movement in moving PRC troops to the region. Time left gives cause to round down from 1% to 0

The military base in Djibouti is currently described as a supply station and concerned with naval operations.  Naturally troops could be moved into Djibouti; however, this would raise an issue at the UN Security Council and most likely result in a move to censure China which it would naturally veto.  There have been disputes between Djibouti and Eritrea; however, nothing available on the internet leads one to consider a current conflict.  Both US Embassies advise caution but have no information concerning conflict between these two nations.
This story has had no news since my last inspection.
No recent news on the Chinese military's website on Djibouti or peacekeeping missions in relation to the dispute - won't happen in the next 5 days.
China doesn't seem to interested in Africa, and the deadline is one week away.
Such move will be only in conjunction with UN and if requested by African parties involved.
New foreign investment dollars in both Eritrea and especially Djibouti are strong incentives for maintaining calm.
Revising down because there are three weeks left.  Also, UN doesn't work during Christmas so there is even less time to arrive at a consensus.

The latest information I could find after a quick google search states that China didn't intend to act as mediator, at least not in the way Qatar did. Furthermore, the limits of an intervention as outlined in the report by the South China Morning Post are quite high (authorization by UN, request by AU and agreement by both Eritrea and Djibouti).  Source: https://raddingtonreport.com/djibouti-struggle-against-terrorism/
China traditionally does not use its military forces outside of Asia. It would break its policy of non-intervention, even if it were a peace force

Statement by H. E. MR. Mohamed Siad Doualeh, Republic of Djibouti ambassador to the United Nations, on the situation in Eritrea, November 14: https://www.un.int/djibouti/news/his-excellency-mr-mohamed-siad-doualeh-addresses-security-council-situation-somalia-and-0 Highlights:  "Djibouti expresses serious concern that for the fifth consecutive mandate, the Monitoring group was not permitted to visit Eritrea... "
"Eritrea should commit to full cooperation with the SEMG, including full access to all information and records the mission deems necessary to review, and all personnel it deems necessary to interview." 
"Following the end of Qatar’s mediation efforts, and after the departure of Qatar’s personnel from the international border, Eritrea moved its military personnel to Ras Doumeira and Doumeira Island, thus contributing to heightened tensions and insecurity and threatening a new outbreak of violence. Alarmed at the possibility of resumption of hostilities, the African Union decided to deploy a fact-finding mission to both Djibouti and Eritrea.
Djibouti has cooperated and facilitated the work of the African Union mission in its endeavor to accomplish its mandate. Eritrea, characteristically, has yet to cooperate with the African Union fact-finding mission.  Djibouti, as called for in the resolution just adopted, fully commits to continue cooperating with the Chairperson of the African Union."  Lowering forecast, granted this is only one side of the argument, but it seems the work to solve this dispute peacefully is being drawn out.
Probability based on stabilization and question closing date. New hostile aggression from Eritrea would be required to create call for outside intervention.

China said only if requested. Eritrea insists Qatar be the only mediator. Djibouti is in the Saudi camp and so may not accept Qatar. The two sides will not likely to agree to this. Still the Chinese could just do it. China likes to quietly project power as the increase troops around the world so probably not now.
No mentioning of any possible engagement: http://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2121547/chinese-troops-head-back-djibouti-desert-live-fire

Today's P.R.C. People's Daily highlights strategic agreement between Djibouti and China.
No specific military measures were announced and as noted below even if PRC troops dispatched to border highly unlikely it would be announced publicly.
PLA not going to take casualties on this ill defined border. 
China continues incremental increases in its military footprint.
While there is a high likelihood that Chinese troops are in the area, they will likely never admit they have anyone there
Despite the Chinese are building up its first base in the region in Djibouti, I can't imagine that they would actively engage on a land based mission.
Deployment of Chinese troops as part of a multinational force would count; but I don't see any movement before Christmas

“The PLA has organised a stand by peacekeeping force of 19 units…With a standby force, China’s peacekeeping force will improve its combat readiness and be able to respond to emergencies more efficiently, said You Haitao, Vice Commander of the PLA.” (http://eng.chinamil.com.cn/view/2017-11/07/content_7815184.htm) “China is playing a bigger role in UN peacekeeping missions, as its troops carry out tasks in many war-torn countries in Africa - they need more of these real-combat drills to prepare them, said Beijing-based military expert Zhou Chenming” (http://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2120754/chinese-troops-two-day-drill-prepare-peacekeeping)  The fact that the Chinese are increasing their peacekeeping force, but for roles under the United Nations, suggests they will not be deploying to the Djibouti-Eritrea region this year; given the number of steps necessary to take before a UN peacekeeping mission reaches the ‘planning’ stage.

Unilateral is likely. Args Ag: Qatar's peace-keeping force was about 200 soldiers? Other countries have bases in Djibouti, will be sensitive to enhanced China role. Args Favour: Eritrea's biggest donor is China, will be happy to accept China's mediation. UN sanctioned peace-keeping is very unlikely by December.
Not probable, but an area where China can extend its influence without others powers complaining excessively

There is too much potential to mediate the dispute and much military strength behind the presence of not only the Chinese but others who have a vested interest in a quiet peaceful resolution to the problem.

Africa News, November 11, 'Eritrea backing armed groups against Ethiopia and Djibouti – U.N. experts': http://www.africanews.com/2017/11/11/eritrea-backing-armed-groups-against-ethiopia-and-djibouti-un-experts/
Clips from Africa News article:
"The document titled: ‘Report of the Monitoring Group on Somalia and Eritrea’ presented to the U.N. Security Council (UNSC), however, emphasized that the said groups do not pose a critical threat to the target nations.
“Eritrea continued to provide support to armed groups intent on destabilizing Ethiopia and Djibouti, including the Benishangul People’s Liberation Movement, the Front for the Restoration of Unity and Democracy (FRUD-Armé), Patriotic Ginbot Sebat (PG7) and the Tigray People’s Democratic Movement.
“While none of these groups poses a critical threat to either Djibouti or Ethiopia, the support of Eritrea for them continues to generate insecurity in the region and undermines the normalization of relations between regional Member States,” the report said." VOA, November 3, 'China Opens First Overseas Military Base': https://www.voanews.com/a/china-overseas-military-base/4099717.html
Clips from VOA article:
"Xi “encouraged them to establish a good image for China’s military and promote international and regional peace and stability”, the ministry said.
Comments: 'Peace and stability' = Main message. "During his visit to the command center, Xi also instructed the armed forces to improve their combat capability and readiness for war, the ministry said."
Comments: Secondary message. See below: Chinese proverb:
A young apprentice, while training in the use of the Chinese sword, asked his teacher why, if he was striving to be inwardly calm and at peace, he needed to learn the ways of a warrior. “Would it not be more tranquil and serene to be a gardener and tend the plants?” he asked. “Tending the garden,” the master replied, “is a relaxing pastime, but it does not prepare one for the inevitable battles of life. It is easy to be calm in a serene setting. To be calm and serene when under attack is much more difficult; therefore, I tell you that it is far better to be a warrior tending his garden rather than a gardener at war.” Adjusting to my initial probability.

Lowering forecast: No news from the Chinese military on a potential peacekeeping mission to the region, along with no recent news on the dispute from the region. If there was a sudden rise in tension/outbreak of conflict then there would be implications for both the French and U.S.: 
The French foreign ministry has not published any recent news on the situation in the Djibouti-Eritrea region. Taking into account the role the french had in the conflict in 2008, one would expect the ministry to make a statement if the situation will/does suddenly escalate. 
https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/
Most recent news from the State department was a travel warning issued September 25, 2017 stating: “U.S. citizens are strongly advised to avoid travel near the Eritrean-Ethiopian border area and Southern Red Sea Region because of the presence of large numbers of Eritrean and Ethiopian troops along the contested border area, and because of the military tensions between the two countries. U.S. citizens should also avoid travel to the contested Eritrea-Djibouti region, where military troops patrol and tensions are high.” (https://travel.state.gov/content/passports/en/alertswarnings/eritrea-travel-warning.html)

China daily doesn't mention any issues between Eritrea and Djibouti: http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2017-10/27/content_33791956.htm
The Djibouti is mentioned, but nothing about getting prepared for a peace mission. It continues to look like Eritrea and Djibouti are not interested in a peace mission, a precondition for China to get involved.

no
not while Eritrea sanctioned by UN

hope i'll be able to take a look at some of those eventually. Many of the titles/subjects/authors look fascinating. i'd particularly like to learn what gates has to say; always struck me as smart, committed, above partisan-bs, served the public for decades, relatively quiet retirement compared to many...

However, the question regarding the ability of China to fully cope with the peacekeeper's mission between Djibouti and Eritrea, despite the solid experience of participating in UN peacekeeping missions, remains contentious. “China is trying to claim itself as a political player who is able to resolve armed conflicts. Yet, it is not clear how much China will cope with this task because China has no great experience in such activities,”  In addition, he said that for the settlement of armed conflicts, it is necessary to have special equipment of the armed forces. These are units that have special light weapons and ammunitions. Furthermore, the peacekeepers should also have the skills to communicate with the local population in English, and also extensive training of the personnel for such peacekeeping operations is required.  “I'm not yet sure that China is able to fully cope with this task. However, the fact that China declares its readiness for a peacekeeping operation indicates that China is gradually becoming a political center of power,” How China’s Base in Djibouti Reveals an ‘Expanding Sphere of Influence’
According to the analyst, China’s growing influence is a concern for the US, Japan and South Korea. 
Despite that, China’s offer to act as a mediator is seen by some as a positive diplomatic gesture.
https://sputniknews.com/africa/201707261055901392-china-wants-to-resolve-djibouti-border-conflict/

COMMENTS:  it does resonates with me tha China is eager to show good diplomatic gestures, while establish8ng its world political role. If this conflict should escalate further, maybe other forces may be willing to enter this arena.

Maintaining forecast for now:  President Xi Jinping “encouraged troops at the Peoples Liberation Army support base in Djibouti to help promote international and regional peace and stability” (http://eng.chinamil.com.cn/view/2017-11/03/content_7812092.htm) 
This doesn’t necessarily mean deploying troops to the disputed Djibouti-Eritrea region; it could include, for example, anti-piracy missions off the coast of somalia. However, Beijing did describe the base as a logistics facility…
There hasn’t been any recent reports on the dispute in the border region. However, this does not necessarily mean that there isn’t fighting ongoing. 
The most recent reports are of fighting within Eritrea, relating to protests: 
http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/11/eritrea-opposition-security-forces-kill-28-protesters-171101171043467.html  @vanschermerhoyt made a good point! https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/610161
Chinese intervention is possible but unlikely.

I sorted thru UN news reports and their upcoming agenda for the month of November and I did not see anything that would indicate an upcoming resolution or authorization by the UN.  Given that there would still have to be action by the AU and then both countries, I'm revising my forecast down.
djbouti is of strategic interest to china.
They're just getting their feet wet. May need a few months to come to terms with their deployment strategies and long-term engagement plans.

This conflict has been going for awhile. China as well as US has military base in Djibouti. UN/US blame Eritrea and have put on sanctions. China would be seen as ignoring those efforts. Not likely as they want to be seen as leader rather than imperialistic.
Updating based on further consideration of the issue.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Readjusted my math to reflect the wording that a deployment could be announced but not executed within the time period. And corrected a previous forecast error.

Lowering forecast: Most recent Chinese Peacekeeping news:
“The 21st Chinese peacekeeping engineer detachment to the Democratic Republic of Congo has recently received the first combat-readiness inspection on equipment from the United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission (K)(MONUSCO) since the detachment began to perform its peacekeeping mission in the Congo in September 2017” 
(http://eng.mod.gov.cn/news/2017-10/23/content_4795419.htm)  
Given that member states send military and police for UN peacekeeping operations, if China sent troops as part of a UN peacekeeping mission would this not resolve the question?  Anyway, with no recent news of escalation between Djibouti and Eritrea, it seems very unlikely that the UN will go through the first 5 stages of forming a new mission in the next two months. (http://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/operations/newoperation.shtml)
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Eritrea is taking advantage of the vacuum left by Qatar.
Ethiopia and the AU have strong financial and political infrastructure investment by the Chinese in addition to the military base. Chinese interests  ( along with other countries that also have a military and economic presence in Djibouti) is for stability and further development in one of the most important strategic areas and shipping lanes of the world. The AU, Ethiopia and Djibouti would welcome Chinese troops in a peace keeping role as China has already volunteered to fill the roll left by Qatar. This would be a win-win for China as they would raise their status and assert their position in Africa by becoming a positive strategic stabilizing force to be reckoned with and counted on when any future conflicts flare up in the future of which, of course, there is an endless potential.
A peace keeping mission by the African Union, who will initiate peacekeeping missions only with the consent of both parties except for dire circumstances to which the border  conflict does not arise,
would probably not be agreed upon by Eritrea
 At some point someone has to step in.

This would be China's first foray into unilateral peacekeeping outside the UN Peacekeeping system.[1] Certainly, we can expect these kinds of operations as China extends its influence and moves forward with the "One Belt, One Road" initiative. However, at this early stage of the country's operations in Djibouti it would be unlikely to see a significant change to the slow pace of China's military influence on the African continent. A commitment of 450 troops [2], the presumed equivalent of what Qatar had on the border, would itself not be a challenge to China's vast army, but in this situation it would represent a considerable stretch. It was just late September that Chinese troops stationed in Djibouti had their first live-fire exercise[3] and their airfield lacks the length required for fixed-wing aircraft that would perform air-support of troops on the ground.[4] China will likely use this naval base in Djibouti for it's intended use [5] before using the base as support for ground operations and pivoting toward more tricky displays of commitment to the African region.  It's also worth noting also that China must be invited to step in here, a move that Eritrea is so far against. [6] We should see African Union observers long before the Chinese government is asked to mediate the conflict and it would take a significant change in the situation before China becomes the best choice for peacekeeping on the border. [7] [1] https://www.usip.org/publications/2016/07/chinas-troop-contributions-un-peacekeeping
[2] https://messengerafrica.com/2017/06/22/factbox-understanding-the-eritrea-djibouti-border-dispute/
[3] http://www.newsweek.com/china-military-base-live-fire-djibouti-africa-670588
[4] https://intpolicydigest.org/2017/08/11/china-military-base-djibouti/
[5] http://opinion.huanqiu.com/editorial/2017-07/10966656.html
[6] http://venturesafrica.com/heres-how-the-international-community-reacts-to-the-eritrea-djibouti-border-dispute/
[7] http://www.africanews.com/2017/07/04/djibouti-requests-au-presence-along-disputed-border-with-eritrea/

The naval base is still being developed and does not appear to have the capacity to support even a limited peacekeeping force. It was reported on 28 September that a wharf is due for construction to resupply naval flotillas. Additionally, there has not been any military activity since a militant attack in 2013, so China feels no need to rush into the area without sufficient support and policial cover.
If china could gather resources there too, or if they see that region as a strategic “outpost“, they will do it.
It tracks with Xi's desire for first world power projection but I think he'll hold off as he tries to work with the US on North Korea...
Could happen. Not before the end of the year, though.
China offered to assist in July, but has taken no action since then. The time-frame is too short.
Barring any further escalation of the situation, this event seems unlikely in the prescribed timeframe.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
Incremental adjustment down for the passage of time.
Lowering due to no recent news from the Djibouti-Eritrea region
Seems highly unlikely that they would do this unilaterally. More likely if it was a U.N. sanctioned peacekeeping mission, and I do not see that happening within the prescribed timeframe.
China will not engage in a militarized foreign policy in the near future.
China will not act by sending troops this year.  We would expect more steps by local authorities, particularly the African Union, to run their course before Chinese troop deployment.
Outstanding data and analysis by @cpschneider at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/588703, thank you, Christian Schneider.

China has three requirements for sending peacekeepers:  1) Authorized by the UN, 2) Requested by the AU, and 3) that both parties agree to it.  Since there are three specific requirements to be met the odds must be lower.  Historically, from the time of the first border conflict and incursions by Eritrea in 2008 to the deployment of Qatari peace-keepers was a process that took two years.  So I think that the time frame of six months to an announcement is too short.  It took just over a month for China to even announce that it would intervene if asked. In my search on the AU's website and for any word on UN authorizations I did not find any.  Furthermore, I could find no information on an outcome from the AU's fact finding mission.  There were no UN resolutions published either and no announcements by Eritrea or Djibouti that they wanted the Chinese to intervene.  This doesn't mean it didn't happen, I could be a poor investigator, but I think given the press it has received already, there would be some kind of published report at this point.

A deployment of Chinese troops seems very unlikely. It seem almost impossible that China deploys a UN sanctioned peace keeping mission by the end of the year. To do so, the UN Security Council would have to authorize such a deployment. A UNSC resolution doing so seems only likely if both parties and most probably the African Union agreed beforehand. If either country would agree to China sending peacekeepers remains unclear (https://www.crisisgroup.org/middle-east-north-africa/gulf-and-arabian-peninsula/dangerous-gulf-horn-how-inter-arab-crisis-fuelling-regional-tensions).  Currently, neither the UNSC nor the AU Peace and Security Council seem to have scheduled deliberations about the situation in the Djibouti-Eritrea border region for this month, suggesting that the current situation is not perceived as urgent by the two bodies. Before authorizing a peace keeping mission, it also seems likely that IOs would use all other means at their hands to deescalate the situation. This would take time. And even if the situation deteriorated rapidly, given the decision-making procedures at least in the UNSC (I don't know much about the AU), a deployment of a peacekeeping mission by the end of the year seems highly unlikely.  In another scenario, China could deploy troops unilaterally (or at the request of Djibouti, perhaps), for example in response to an emerging crisis that directly threatens Chinese interest in Djibouti or in the context of a search-and-rescue operation. This seems unlikely - also because Chinese troops are still in the process of adapting to the conditions under which they have to operate in Djibouti (http://supchina.com/2017/09/25/live-fire-drill-djibouti-chinas-latest-political-current-affairs-news/) - but cannot be fully ruled out.
China has just started to establish a military foothold in Djibouti and they will be reluctant to get involved in that border war.

Going in higher than the consensus; partly due to the wording of the question (as others have mentioned) such as announcing troop deployment and the definition of “Chinese troops” as @joew92 said (will watch out for anything you report in response to the clarification you sent – thanks!)  Despite China’s non-interference policy, in the last year they have offered to mediate relations between Saudi Arabia-Iran, India-Pakistan and Myanmar-Bangladesh. They previously mediated for South Sudan in 2013, “when the Horn of Africa nations asked China to help with mediation.” (http://www.scmp.com/comment/insight-opinion/article/2113416/intervene-or-not-chinas-foreign-policy-experiment-south) 
“China’s position in the South Sudanese civil war revolved around strict adherence to its non-interference principle, urging parties in the conflict to seek political solutions, direct mediation and deployment of combat troops under the auspices of the UN Peacekeeping Mission in South Sudan” (https://www.google.co.uk/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=6&ved=0ahUKEwjA_Oq0htLWAhXCKsAKHTwcDa8QFghEMAU&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.defense.gouv.fr%2Fcontent%2Fdownload%2F498731%2F8484271%2Ffile%2FOBS_Chine_201701-NA14-Chine%2520Sud%2520Soudan.pdf&usg=AOvVaw0v_n9idUgPgGVgd5nIpeYf)  China’s “national interests” are at risk if the Djibouti-Eritrea dispute escalates. The ‘One Belt, One Road’ maritime route goes through the Gulf of Aden and up the Red Sea (hence the recently constructed naval base in Djibouti). However, the Chinese Ambassador to Eritrea, Shu Zhan, told SCMP “China’s intention to mediate in the border issue has not connection with the Djibouti Port and signals no change in China’s longstanding non-interference policy.” (http://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2103947/china-offers-mediate-djibouti-eritrea-border-row-it)
That being said, China had invested heavily in South Sudan’s oil infrastructure and both sides of the warring parties knew that without Chinese investment, there would be limited financial income.  I looked at the likelihood of another country taking the position Qatar once held, or the possibility of Qatar returning to the area:
In “November 2008, Iran had offered to mediate the conflict between Eritrea and Djibouti, citing it’s closeness to both countries…After dubious backdoor deals Djibouti severed diplomatic relations with Iran in 2016.” 
“Eritrea has sought to extend its diplomacy by forging new alliances. It raised its cooperation with Saudi Arabia and the UAE.”
(https://issafrica.s3.amazonaws.com/site/uploads/ear8.pdf) 
“Djibouti has allowed the establishment of a military base by Saudi Arabia on its territory. Eritrea has allowed the UAE and Saudi Arabia to use the Assab Port” 
However, “Ethiopia is concerned by Eritrea’s alliance with Saudi Arabia” (https://issafrica.org/iss-today/saudi-arabia-qatar-rift-rattles-the-region) 
As other forecasters have said, Eritrea wants Qatar to be the only mediator in the matter for internal reasons. The likelihood of Qatar going back to being mediator is low until the GCC dispute is resolved. It was portrayed that both Eritrea and Djibouti sided with Saudi Arabia in the dispute which is likely what prompted Qatar to leave the peacekeeping position. Looks more likely that China would get the position.  Also taking into account the Chinese 19th Party Congress, set for October 18th 2017. This scmp.com article (http://www.scmp.com/news/china/policies-politics/article/2109388/reading-between-lines-what-watch-chinas-most-important) highlights the things to watch out for, which include: “Xi will set out the party’s priorities and general policy directions for his second term. A wide range of areas will be covered – from the economy, political system, culture, people’s livelihood, ecology, defense and foreign policy to the party’s own development.” Plus, “the Central Military Commission (CMC), the overall high command of the PLA, is also due for a shake-up at the congress.” 
Any announcements of troop deployment could fall under the time period around the National People’s Congress (NPC) in March, rather than the 19th Congress. It’s also possible that the upcoming Party congress will postpone any decision relating to Djibouti-Eritrea to post-NPC.  However, I agree with @aaseawaf15 that if the Chinese were to send troops, it would likely be under the UN as blue helmets (as they did in South Sudan). Shu Zhan also said “The disputes over Dumeira Mountain have been recurring and China have been mediating in it for a long time, mostly through the mechanism of the African Union. I don’t see much of a difference this time.”( http://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2103947/china-offers-mediate-djibouti-eritrea-border-row-it)  I will be looking out for any escalation in the border dispute, along with Xi’s policy directions, and any announcements from the AU or UN.

Reducing probability on the basis of outstanding data and analysis by @ebeeler at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/586448. Welcome, Erich Beeler, to this platform. I hope you become one of the HFC forecasters.

A couple of thoughts to start with: 
First of all, it is unclear to me what exactly might be considered a deployment of Chinese troops - deployment with UN peacekeepers, multilateral deployment under some joint command, unilateral deployment of the PLA - so I sent in a request for clarification. I will update based on those results.  In the meantime, I mostly aggregated some of the other forecasts and added some thoughts of my own.  I think it is pretty unlikely that China would intervene unilaterally - reversing a long-standing non-interventionist policy, particularly when doing so would mean unilateral action in one of the most geostrategically critical areas in the world. Intervening militarily would risk increasing global sensitivity to Chinese expansion and incense other actors in the region. Specifically, this could put an early damper on China's One Belt-One Road efforts and increase regional outcry over its expansion efforts in the South China Sea.  The greater likelihood, I think, is the deployment of a UN peacekeeping force. Even this, however, I think is quite unlikely, as the UN has been hesitant to deploy a force in this conflict in it's ~20 year history.  I will likely update upon further research and consideration.

China states that it would only send troops if the UN, requested by AU and agreed by both parties. http://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2103947/china-offers-mediate-djibouti-eritrea-border-row-it
Eritrea is servicing currently as head of UNSC, and would like to get rid of their arms sanctions from UN. Therefore Eritrea is not interested in escalation, it also don't agree to a fact finding mission by AU. There's a history of Djibouti-Eritrea conflict dating back to 2008. So preconditions for China are not satisifed. China will stick to their statements and not show imperialistic behavior.
Although eager to expand influence having a base in Djibouti would seem to rule it out as an impartial peace keeping force.

Reducing my forecast because I haven't seen any new news suggesting active discussion of this in the AU or the UN, and I haven't seen any new suggesting a perception that the border dispute is worsening and Chinese involvement is important.
A step too far for a re-emerging empire that made too many bad decisions in the past

Comments: Live-fire drills at their Djibouti barracks. Incremental adjustment up. 
Quartz, September 26, 'China’s vision of itself as the world’s peacekeeper starts in Africa': https://qz.com/1087297/china-in-africa-chinas-vision-of-itself-as-the-worlds-peacekeeper-starts-in-africa/
Clip from Quartz article:
"Over the last 15 years, China has ramped up its role in peacekeeping missions. Of the five permanent members of the UN Security Council, it is the biggest contributor of peacekeepers and is among the world’s top 12 largest contributors of the troops. Chinese president Xi Jinping has pledged to expand China’s contribution to 8,000, from less than 3,000 deployed now." South China Morning Post, September 25,'Live-fire show of force by troops from China’s first overseas military base - Armed forces send message of combat readiness to Djibouti militants and other potential attackers, observers say': http://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2112780/live-fire-show-force-troops-chinas-first-overseas
Clips from Post article:
"Troops arrived at the base – China’s first overseas garrison – less than two months ago and the drill was meant to test the personnel’s capacity to handle a range of weapons and tasks in extreme heat, humidity and salinity, the report said." “The live-fire training will help explore a new training model for the [Chinese] overseas garrison.”
Footage aired by state-run CCTV showed PLA marine corps using various weapons – from pistols to automatic rifles, sniper rifles and machine guns – to fire at targets.
Beijing-based military expert Li Jie said the troops had to be on combat alert at all times because of the region’s complex political conditions and Djibouti’s geographic importance." Xinhua, September 21, 'Spotlight: China backbone force in UN peace operations': http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-09/22/c_136628000.htm
Clips from above Xinhua article:
"HIGH-VALUE PEACEKEEPERS
China dispatches "high-value, hard-to-source enabler troops" and has recently begun to provide combat troops, marking a significant change in its deployment profile, according to related reports.
"What is remarkable is that the contributions of China are very high- quality," said Lacroix, recalling his visit to Juba of South Sudan with his predecessor Herve Ladsous, where he saw himself China's contributions there.
"I was deeply impressed by the quality of the Chinese contingent, qualified people and quality equipment -- this is very important," he added.
Ladsous, UN under-secretary-general for peacekeeping operations from 2011 to 2017, and Atul Khare, the current UN under-secretary-general for the United Nations Department of Field Support, truly appreciated Chinese peacekeepers for their "great professionalism, dedication and generosity."
They said the well-equipped Chinese peacekeeping troops are a reliable force in UN peacekeeping operations and they look forward to a greater role played by China in UN peacekeeping missions.
"China now has become over recent years a very important contributor," Ladsous told Xinhua. "Chinese units are very well-equipped and are well-trained."
"Chinese peacekeepers have never ever had any misconduct of discipline," Khare said against a backdrop of alleged sexual abuse committed in Africa by peacekeepers from other countries." Related:

This is a very rough forecast, because there is a lot of information that is hard to get. China offered to deploy troops in July on three conditions: 1. A request from the AU; 2. Agreement from both parties; 3. UN authorization. I haven't seen anything public from the AU, so I think the request from the AU is probably being debated behind closed doors. This may be a topic of discussion in the margins of the UNGA, among African and non-African nations, and in the absence of any specific information on the discussion I estimate a 25% chance that the AU will request China's involvement soon after the end of the UNGA, with a 50% chance that it will be followed by UN authorization and agreement by Djibouti and Eritrea by the end of the year. That makes a 12.5% chance overall. I add to that a 5% chance that violence will break out on the border and the decision will be expedited. Rounding off, that makes 18%. If no request comes from the AU by the end of September, I'll drop that to 5%.
China won't act without a UN mandate.

My rationale that China will deploy troops to Eritrea--Djibouti, before 29 December 2017, is one, it follows President Xi's foreign policy of expansion into Africa and Latin America; two, both Djibouti and Eritrea are reported as wanting outside mediation for their dispute since Qatar has withdrawn.  Part of his foreign policy, is his New Era of China-Africa Win-Win Cooperation and Common Development, which he announced at the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC) December 4, 2015. His Foreign Minister reiterated it three months later. Analyst added it was a military expansion as well. Sea ports and naval bases are just an element of that expansion and influence. We have seen Beijing use its commercial know-how and financial muscle to secure ownership over the Arabian Sea port of Gwadar, Pakistan, a strategic trading base, only to enlist it later into military service. This is China's template. The Djibouti naval base was next, which secures China's presence at the Bab al-Mandab Strait. So, why would China deploy troops to Djibouti-Eritrea? Once Qatar withdrew it troops, Djibouti quickly requested support from the African Union (AU) and Kuang Weilin, the Chinese Ambassador to the African Union, suggested that China will consider sending troops to the border. Eritrea had earlier said they would work only with Qatar. This was prior to China offering to mediate. The African Union Commission Chairman Moussa Faki Mahamat has announced that he is sending a delegation to the Djibouti border to monitor developments (no troops). The other option was UN troops. Eritrea said it sees ‘no real value’ in allowing a visit by a UN monitoring group. So, since both Djibouti and Eritrea are reported as wanting outside mediation, after the AU's investigation, they could easily be the agent to recommend China as the mediator who could then deploy their troops. The only country needed to be somewhat swayed is Eritrea. China is Eritrea's largest investor and creditor and trading partner.  What would change my thinking would be tension over the border to die down or for the two countries to somehow resolve it themselves. The later seems unlikely. Here's a view from Russia about the matter: https://sputniknews.com/africa/201707261055901392-china-wants-to-resolve-djibouti-border-conflict/ The contention in the article is that China wants the increased prestige that comes with peacekeeping, and also to preempt other powers from intervening in a region where China has been developing a strategic interest. This makes sense. But at the same time, the article hints that China has no clear idea of what peacekeeping entails. That's probably untrue, but China's lack of experience in this field may mean that the debate in China over whether and how to proceed may not resolve soon. And yes, I know Sputnik news is a propaganda site, but nothing in the article struck me as particularly contentious. Propaganda sites have to publish some hard news and bona fide analysis so they have credibility when they publish propaganda.

The South China Morning Post reported the following: China opened its first overseas naval base in Djibouti in August 2017. China has presented the facility as a support base to run anti-piracy operations in waters along Africa’s east coast as well as peacekeeping and humanitarian missions in the region. China's state news agency Xinhua  did not disclose how many military personnel would be stationed at the facility or when it would become fully operational. But previous mainland reports have put the size of the deployment at 10,000. The lease runs for a decade with China paying US$20 million a year. But given it sits at the shipping choke point of the Gulf of Aden which opens to the Suez Canal and beyond, China’s regional neighbors including Japan, India and Vietnam were likely to view the deployment with alarm, mainland experts said. Djibouti already hosts several foreign military bases, including one each from the US and Japan, two strategic rivals to Beijing. A base by Saudi Arabia is also under construction in Djibouti. My thinking is based on the report that at least 10,000 Chinese troops will be sent to support the new naval base compared to the 4,000 U. S. troops at its base. Sending in even more Chinese troops would fit into President Xi Jinping's expansion desires plus give China better control of the Bab al-Mandab Strait. From China's perspective, It makes sense to have more troops there. At this point, China needs to influence the two countries in conflict and the African Union, who has sent in an investigative body and the UN. The only body that needs to be courted somewhat is Eritrea, which seems very doable.

But direct military intervention is still not an option, Shu said. “If China would send a peacekeeping force there, everything would strictly follow three principles – authorised by the United Nations, requested by the African Union, and agreed by both parties.

Deploying peacekeepers on its own would be a major change in Chinese foreign policy and the security council hasn't shown any signs of authorizing a peacekeeping force on the Eritrea-Djubouti border or of extending the mandate of the force along the Eritrea-Ethiopia border.

Such a move would, shall we say, lack subtlety.  I think the PRC would believe the time not to be quite ripe for This Sort Of Thing.  (Full disclosure:  The PRC do not confide their plans, either long-term or short-term, to me.  I think they should, but there it is.)

Here's and overview of Qatar's recent withdrawal: http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/2017/06/qatar-army-djibouti-eritrea-border-170618100118290.html It's probable that somebody's troops will be deployed, but the prestige China would get from deploying its own troops is offset by the risk of having its troops in a conflict zone. Things can easily become unmanageable, which leaves the intervening power the choice of taking sides, withdrawing, or doing nothing. None of these courses of action is risk-free, and the best way to not be placed in such a position is to just stay out of the conflict. Moreover, the Chinese logistical base in Djibouti is only recently established, and putting another 500 troops equipped for peacekeeping on the ground may be not be practical this year. However, the Chinese have said they're willing to send troops to monitor the area, and they don't make announcements like that lightly, so this bears watching.
